case_name: Raghutilaka Tirtha Sripadangalavaru Swamiji v. Government of Mysore

facts.text: This appeal arises from a writ petition filed by the appellant Raghutilaka Tirtha Sripadangalavaru Swamiji in the Mysore High Court challenging validity of s. 6(2) of the Mysore Tenancy Act, 1952 and notification issued under it on March 31, 1952

anchor.surface_text: This appeal arises from a writ petition filed by the appellant, Raghutilaka Tirtha Sripadangalavaru Swamiji, in the Mysore High Court challenging the validity of s. 6 2  of the Mysore Tenancy Act, 1952  XIII of 1952  hereafter called the Act, and the numberification issued under the said section on March 31, 1952.

facts.text: High Court rejected appellant's contention that s.6(2) and notification infringed Arts. 14, 19(1)(f), 26, 31, 31A and held them valid and constitutional

anchor.surface_text: The appellants case as set out in his writ petition before the High Court was that the impugned section as well as the numberification issued under it infringed his fundamental rights guaranteed under Arts. 14, 19 1  f , 26, 31 and 31A of the Constitution. This companytention has been rejected by the High Court and it has been held that the section and the numberification under challenge are valid and companystitutional.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under Art. 133 but refused under Art. 132

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied for a certificate from the High Court, both under Art. 132 and Art. 133 of the Constitution. The High Court granted him certificate under Art. 133, but refused to certify the case under Art. 132.

facts.text: Appellant applied to Supreme Court for liberty to raise constitutional interpretation question and permission was granted

anchor.surface_text: There after the appellant applied to this Court for liberty to raise a question about the interpretation of the Constitution and permission has been accorded to the appellant accordingly. That is how the present appeal has companye to this Court.

facts.text: Appellant owns 6 acres and 30 ghuntas of garden land in village Mulbagilu in Taluka Thirthahalli in Shimoga district

anchor.surface_text: The appellant owns 6 acres and 30 ghuntas of garden land in village Mulbagilu in Taluka Thirthahalli in the district of Shimoga.

facts.text: Respondent No. 3 Ramappa Gowda is tenant of appellant's land

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 3, Ramappa, Gowda, is his tenant in respect of this land.

facts.text: Registered lease deed executed in favour of respondent No. 3 by appellant on March 11, 1943 for annual rent of 82-1/2 maunds of areca plus Rs. 17/12 cash

anchor.surface_text: A registered lease deed was executed in favour of respondent No. 3 by the appellant on March 11, 1943 under this document respondent No. 3 undertook to pay 82-1/2 maunds of areca in addition to Rs. 17/12-in cash as rent per year.

facts.text: In 1955 respondent No. 3 filed application before Tehsildar of Thirthahalli (respondent No. 2) under section 12 of the Act to fix standard rent, Tenancy case 85 of 1955-56

anchor.surface_text: In 1955 respondent No. 3 filed an application before respondent No. 2, the Tehsildar of Thirthahalli, under section 12 of the Act and claimed that the standard rent payable by him to the appellant should be fixed  Tenancy case 85 of 1955-56 .

facts.text: Government of Mysore (respondent No. 1) issued notification No. R9. 10720/L.S. 73-54-2 on March 28/29, 1955 under s. 6 fixing standard rent at one third of produce for lands of appellant's category

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile respondent No. 1, the Government of Mysore, had, in exercise of the powers companyferred on it by s. 6 of the Act, issued a numberification No. R9. 10720/L.S. 73-54-2 on March 28/29, 1955. This numberification purported to fix the standard rent for lands of the category to which the appellants land belongs at one third of the produce.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition in High Court on December 16, 1955 aggrieved by the 1955 notification claiming s.6(2) and notification ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: Feeling aggrieved by this numberification the appellant filed the present writ petition in the High Court on December 16, 1955. His case was that s. 6 2  as well as the numberification issued under it were ultra vires, invalid and inoperative.

facts.text: Mysore Tenancy Act, 1952 (XIII of 1952) passed to regulate landlord-tenant relations for agricultural lands in Mysore except Bellary District

anchor.surface_text: The Act has been passed by the Mysore Legislature because it was thought necessary to regulate the law which governs the relations of landlords and tenants of agricultural lands and to regulate and impose restrictions on the transfer of agricultural lands, dwelling houses, sites and lands appurtenant thereto belonging to or occupied by agriculturists in the State of Mysore except Bellary District and to make provisions for certain other purposes appearing in the Act.

facts.text: Notification under s.6(2) fixes maximum rent at one-third for Schedule I Maidan areas and one-fourth for Schedule II Malanad areas from April 1, 1955

anchor.surface_text: This numberification has been issued in exercise of the powers companyferred on the State Government by s. 6 2  and is provides that the rate of maximum rent payable by the tenants of lands situated in the areas specified in Schedule I and Schedule II to the numberification shall be one-third and one-fourth respectively of the crop or crops raised on such lands with effect from the year companymencing on April 1, 1955.

facts.text: Maidan lands are plains, Malanad lands are hilly tracts; classification well known in Mysore accounting for rainfall, cultivation, living conditions, labour, produce

anchor.surface_text: Schedule I deals with Maidan areas in which the maximum rent or rents shall be one-third of the crop or crops and Schedule II deals with Malanad areas in which the maximum rate of rent shall be one-fourth of the crop or crops raised. It appears that the classification of lands between Maidan an Malanad lands is well known in Mysore. Maidan lands are lands on the plains, whereas Malanad are lands on hilly tracts.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld validity of s.6 of Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1948 in Vasantal Maganbhai Sanjanwala v. State of Bombay

anchor.surface_text: The validity of s. 6 of the Bombay Act was challenged before this Court in Vasantal Maganbhai Sanjanwala v. The State of Bombay and it has been held that the said section is valid.

facts.text: Mysore High Court took view that notification did not make exception swallow general rule of s.6(1)

anchor.surface_text: That, in substances, is the view which the Mysore High companyrt has taken in the matter and we think that the said view is right.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted permission for present appeal

anchor.surface_text: permission has been accorded to the appellant accordingly. That is how the present appeal has companye to this Court.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the classification of lands between Maidan an Malanad lands is well known in Mysore. Maidan lands are lands on the plains, whereas Malanad are lands on hilly tracts. The distinction between the two categories of lands takes into account the different conditions of rain fall, the different nature of the cultivation, the difference in the living conditions and the availability of labour and the difference in the quantity and the quality of the produce.

concepts.interpretation: Classification into Maidan (plains, 1/3 rent) and Malanad (hilly, 1/4 rent) held valid; based on rainfall, cultivation, living conditions, labour, produce quality/quantity.

This argument is based on the decision of the House of Lords in Macbeth v. Ashley

issues.text: Whether Section 6(2) of the Mysore Tenancy Act, 1952 and the notification issued under it infringe Articles 14, 19(1)(f), 26, 31 and 31A of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: challenging the validity of s. 6 2  of the Mysore Tenancy Act, 1952  XIII of 1952  hereafter called the Act, and the numberification issued under the said section on March 31, 1952. The appellants case as set out in his writ petition before the High Court was that the impugned section as well as the numberification issued under it infringed his fundamental rights guaranteed under Arts. 14, 19 1  f , 26, 31 and 31A of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether Section 6(2) of the Mysore Tenancy Act, 1952 is valid, notwithstanding differences in preamble and lack of distinction between irrigated and non-irrigated lands or minimum rent provision compared to Bombay Tenancy Act?

anchor.surface_text: The validity of s. 6 of the Bombay Act was challenged before this Court in Vasantal Maganbhai Sanjanwala v. The State of Bombay and it has been held that the said section is valid. The reasons given by this Court in upholding the validity of s. 6 of the Bombay Act apply with equal force in support of the validity of s. 6 of the Mysore Act and so the point raised by the appellant in challenging the validity of the impugned section is really companyered by the earlier decision of this Court.

issues.text: Whether the impugned notification issued under Section 6(2) is invalid?

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, satisfied that the case of the impugned section is substantially similar to the case of s. 6 of the Bombay Act with which this Court was companycerned in the case of Sanjanwala and the challenge to the validity of section in the present appeal must, therefore, be held to be companyered by the said decision. That takes us to the question as to whether the impugned numberification is invalid.

issues.text: Whether the classification of lands into Maidan and Malanad areas in the notification under Section 6(2) is reasonable and violates Article 14?

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the classification of lands between Maidan an Malanad lands is well known in Mysore. Maidan lands are lands on the plains, whereas Malanad are lands on hilly tracts. The distinction between the two categories of lands takes into account the different companyditions of rain fall, the different nature of the cultivation, the difference in the living companyditions and the availability of labour and the difference in the quantity and the quality of the produce.

issues.text: Whether Section 6(2) is a proviso or exception to Section 6(1) such that the notification under Section 6(2) allows the exception to swallow the general rule?

anchor.surface_text: The argument is that s. 6 1  lays down a general rule and s. 6 2  provides for an exception to the said general rule. On that assumption it is contended that an exception cannot be allowed to swallow up the general rule and that is precisely what the notification purports to do. This argument is based on the decision of the House of Lords in Macbeth v. Ashley

arguments.claim: Section 6(2) of the Mysore Tenancy Act, 1952 and the notification issued under it infringe Articles 14, 19(1)(f), 26, 31 and 31A of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The appellants case as set out in his writ petition before the High Court was that the impugned section as well as the numberification issued under it infringed his fundamental rights guaranteed under Arts. 14, 19 1  f , 26, 31 and 31A of the Constitution.

arguments.court_reasoning: Not impressed; policy of social justice writ large on face of Act despite preamble; agrarian reform object obvious from scheme

arguments.court_reasoning: Not essential for prescribing maximum ceiling; distinction irrelevant as section fixes maximum, not minimum

anchor.surface_text: Then it is argued that the Bombay Act while prescribing a maximum has taken the precaution of also prescribing a minimum and the absence of the latter provision makes a material difference.

arguments.court_reasoning: Sanjanwala decision upheld Bombay s.6 without reliance on minimum rent provision which was added later

arguments.claim: Notification under s.6(2) invalid as inconsistent with s.6(1); s.6(2) is exception/proviso that swallows general rule of s.6(1)

anchor.surface_text: It is urged by Mr. Shukla that the impugned notification is invalid, because it is inconsistent with the provisions of s. 6 1 . The argument is that s. 6 1  lays down a general rule and s. 6 2  provides for an exception to the said general rule.

arguments.court_reasoning: s.6(2) not proviso or exception but independent coordinate provision allowing lower maximum area-wise; harmonious construction; Macbeth distinguished as not evasion and s.6(2) authorizes area-wide fixation

arguments.court_reasoning: Classification well-known in Mysore; based on intelligible differentia of rainfall, cultivation nature, living conditions, labour availability, produce quantity/quality with rational nexus to rent fixation

arguments.claim: Section 6 of Mysore Act valid as substantially similar to s.6 Bombay Act upheld in Sanjanwala

anchor.surface_text: The validity of s. 6 of the Bombay Act was challenged before this Court in Vasantal Maganbhai Sanjanwala v. The State of Bombay and it has been held that the said section is valid.

arguments.claim: Section 6(2) and notification valid and constitutional not infringing fundamental rights

arguments.claim: s.6(1) and s.6(2) are independent coordinate provisions; s.6(2) permits lower area-wise ceilings without swallowing s.6(1)
Macbeth v Ashley does not apply as s.6(2) not structured as proviso for particular localities but authorizes general area-based lower rates

holdings.text: Section 6(2) of the Mysore Tenancy Act, 1952 and the notification issued under it do not infringe Articles 14, 19(1)(f), 26, 31 and 31A of the Constitution; they are valid and constitutional.

anchor.surface_text: This contention has been rejected by the High Court and it has been held that the section and the notification under challenge are valid and constitutional. The appellant then applied for a certificate from the High Court, both under Art. 132 and Art. 133 of the Constitution. The High Court granted him certificate under Art. 133, but refused to certify the case under Art. 132.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms High Court; detailed analysis rejects Art.14 classification challenge, other rights as agrarian reform; follows Sanjanwala precedent.

holdings.text: Section 6 of the Mysore Tenancy Act, 1952 is valid; challenge covered by Sanjanwala decision upholding similar Bombay s.6.

anchor.surface_text: The validity of s. 6 of the Bombay Act was challenged before this Court in Vasantal Maganbhai Sanjanwala v. The State of Bombay and it has been held that the said section is valid. The reasons given by this Court in upholding the validity of s. 6 of the Bombay Act apply with equal force in support of the validity of s. 6 of the Mysore Act and so the point raised by the appellant in challenging the validity of the impugned section is really covered by the earlier decision of this Court. Mr. Shukla, however, contends that the preamble to the Act differs from the preamble of the Bombay Act...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Substantially similar to Bombay Act; rejects distinctions on preamble, irrigated/non-irrigated classification, absence of minimum rent as non-essential.

holdings.text: The impugned notification under Section 6(2) is valid and not invalid.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, satisfied that the case of the impugned section is substantially similar to the case of s. 6 of the Bombay Act with which this Court was concerned in the case of Sanjanwala and the challenge to the validity of section in the present appeal must, therefore, be held to be covered by the said decision. That takes us to the question as to whether the impugned notification is invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from validity of empowering s.6(2); classification reasonable; not inconsistent with s.6(1).

holdings.text: Classification of lands into Maidan (plains) and Malanad (hilly tracts) areas for fixing maximum rent at 1/3 and 1/4 respectively is reasonable and does not violate Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: Schedule I deals with Maidan areas in which the maximum rent or rents shall be one-third of the crop or crops and Schedule II deals with Malanad areas in which the maximum rate of rent shall be one-fourth of the crop or crops raised. It appears that the classification of lands between Maidan an Malanad lands is well known in Mysore. Maidan lands are lands on the plains, whereas Malanad are lands on hilly tracts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Intelligible differentia based on rainfall, cultivation nature, living conditions, labour availability, produce quality/quantity; rational nexus to rent fixation objective.

holdings.text: Section 6(2) is not a proviso or exception to Section 6(1); it is an independent coordinate provision permitting lower maximum rent area-wise; notification does not allow exception to swallow the general rule.

anchor.surface_text: The argument is that s. 6 1 lays down a general rule and s. 6 2 provides for an exception to the said general rule. On that assumption it is contended that an exception cannot be allowed to swallow up the general rule and that is precisely what the notification purports to do. This argument is based on the decision of the House of Lords in Macbeth v. Ashley... That, in substance, is the view which the Mysore High Court has taken in the matter and we think that the said view is right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading and harmonious construction; distinguishes Macbeth as not evasion; s.6(2) authorizes area-wide lower ceilings explicitly; affirms High Court.

holdings.text: Preamble difference from Bombay Act does not distinguish s.6; social justice policy inherent in Act's scheme for agrarian reform.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Shukla, however, contends that the preamble to the Act differs from the preamble of the Bombay Act inasmuch as the latter preamble refers to the fact that Act was passed inter alia for the purpose of improving the economic and social conditions of peasants... We are not impressed by this argument.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrarian reform object obvious from provisions despite preamble wording.

anchor.surface_text: The validity of s. 6 of the Bombay Act was challenged before this Court in Vasantal Maganbhai Sanjanwala v. The State of Bombay and it has been held that the said section is valid. The reasons given by this Court in upholding the validity of s. 6 of the Bombay Act apply with equal force in support of the validity of s. 6 of the Mysore Act and so the point raised by the appellant in challenging the validity of the impugned section is really covered by the earlier decision of this Court. Mr. Shukla, however, contends that the preamble to the Act differs from the preamble of the Bombay Act...
That, in substances, is the view which the Mysore High companyrt has taken in the matter and we think that the said view is right.

That takes us to the question as to whether the impugned notification is invalid.

anchor.surface_text: Schedule I deals with Maidan areas in which the maximum rent or rents shall be one-third of the crop or crops and Schedule II deals with Malanad areas in which the maximum rate of rent shall be one-fourth of the crop or crops raised. It appears that the classification of lands between Maidan an Malanad lands is well known in Mysore. Maidan lands are lands on the plains, whereas Malanad are lands on hilly tracts.
That, in substances, is the view which the Mysore High companyrt has taken in the matter and we think that the said view is right.

anchor.surface_text: The argument is that s. 6 1 lays down a general rule and s. 6 2 provides for an exception to the said general rule. On that assumption it is contended that an exception cannot be allowed to swallow up the general rule and that is precisely what the notification purports to do. This argument is based on the decision of the House of Lords in Macbeth v. Ashley... That, in substance, is the view which the Mysore High Court has taken in the matter and we think that the said view is right.
